mads:mads.mads:note: Brill's New Pauly: "Hellenica Oxyrhynichia, Two series of papyrus fragments, both 2nd cent. AD.: P Oxy. 842 = PLond., year of discovery 1906, ed. by Grenfell and Hunt (who called the anonymous author P. = Papyrus) and PSI 1304 = PFlor., year of discovery 1942, belonging to one and the same work of history from the first half of the 4th cent. BC and comprising a total of c. 20 pages of Greek history (with gaps!). There is also possibly another new fragment.... The Hellenica Oxyrhynchia form a valuable and independent parallel tradition to Xen. Hell. bks. 1 and 2, and via Ephorus form the basis of Diodorus' description in bks. 13 and 14... On the question of authorship, numerous studies have led to the following identifications:...Ephorus, Theopompus, Androtion, Daimachus, Cratippus,." he most likely candidate is Cratippus of Athens (FGrH 64), who was unjustly called by Jacoby a ‘late fraud’, but was actually an important historian..." Meister, Klaus (Berlin), “Hellenica Oxyrhynchia”, in: Brill’s New Pauly, Antiquity volumes edited by: Hubert Cancik and , Helmuth Schneider. Consulted online on 11 September 2017
